articles.headline: Dow Surges on Hints of a Cut in Interest Rates
articles.snippet: The Dow soared to its biggest one-day gain in more than four years on Wednesday after a top Federal Reserve official hinted at another interest rate cut.
articles.abstract: The Dow soared to its biggest one-day gain in more than four years on Wednesday after a top Federal Reserve official hinted at another interest rate cut.
articles.lead_paragraph: Capping a series of wild swings, the Dow Jones industrial average soared to its biggest one-day percentage gain in more than four years yesterday after a top Federal Reserve official hinted at another interest rate cut and oil fell below $91 a barrel.

articles.headline: Size Limits for Cable Look Likely
articles.snippet: The head of the F.C.C. has proposed quick adoption of a rule that would prevent Comcast, the nation’s largest cable company, from growing larger.
articles.abstract: The head of the F.C.C. has proposed quick adoption of a rule that would prevent Comcast, the nation’s largest cable company, from growing larger.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 — Coming off a setback at the hands of the cable television industry, the head of the Federal Communications Commission moved to reassert himself on Wednesday by proposing that the commission quickly adopt a rule that would prevent Comcast, the nation’s biggest cable company, from becoming larger, commission officials said.

articles.headline: As Lenders Tighten Flow of Credit, Growth at Risk
articles.snippet: Credit flowing to American companies is drying up at a pace not seen in decades, intensifying fears of recession.
articles.abstract: Credit flowing to American companies is drying up at a pace not seen in decades, intensifying fears of recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: Credit flowing to American companies is drying up at a pace not seen in decades, threatening the creation of jobs and the expansion of businesses, while intensifying worries that the economy may be headed for recession.

articles.headline: For Musharraf, Reduced Power as the President
articles.snippet: Resigning as Pakistan’s army chief will leave Pervez Musharraf with vastly reduced powers and Washington with a far more complex Pakistan to deal with in its fight against Al Qaeda and the Taliban.
articles.abstract: Resigning as Pakistan’s army chief will leave Pervez Musharraf with vastly reduced powers and Washington with a far more complex Pakistan to deal with in its fight against Al Qaeda and the Taliban.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 28 — A day after resigning as army chief, Pervez Musharraf will be sworn in as a civilian president on Thursday, leaving him with vastly reduced powers and Washington with a far more complex Pakistan to deal with in its fight against Al Qaeda and the Taliban.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: $200 Billion to Invest, but in China
articles.snippet: In contrast to other sovereign wealth funds, China’s state-run investment fund has no immediate plans to take a large stake in any foreign company.
articles.abstract: In contrast to other sovereign wealth funds, China’s state-run investment fund has no immediate plans to take a large stake in any foreign company.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Nov. 28  As governments in the Middle East take big stakes in American companies, China’s state-run investment fund has quietly shifted its focus from overseas deals to bolstering the country’s troubled banking system.

articles.headline: An Airline Shrugs at Oil Prices
articles.snippet: Southwest Airlines could soon be standing head and shoulders above the competition because it loaded up years ago on hedges against higher fuel prices.
articles.abstract: Southwest Airlines could soon be standing head and shoulders above the competition because it loaded up years ago on hedges against higher fuel prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Southwest Airlines, in danger for much of this year of losing its quirky dominance in the domestic airline industry, could soon be standing, once again, head and shoulders above the competition.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Rivals Exchange Jabs in Testy Debate
articles.snippet: Slashing confrontations between the candidates reflected the wide-open nature of the race.
articles.abstract: Slashing confrontations between the candidates reflected the wide-open nature of the race.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Republican presidential candidates engaged in a slashing debate last night over immigration and other issues, confronting one another in testy exchanges that reflected the wide-open nature of the race in the final sprint toward the Iowa caucuses.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Marc Santora

articles.headline: Microsoft Challenges the iPod (Again)
articles.snippet: The new Zune photo/video/music player fixes many mistakes that made the original Zune a washout.
articles.abstract: The new Zune photo/video/music player fixes many mistakes that made the original Zune a washout.
articles.lead_paragraph: Don’t look now, but Microsoft might finally be getting the hang of hardware.
